facts.text: The appellant was appointed by the Local Self-Government Department, Government of Rajasthan by order of appointment dated 27.11.1974, and posted as Lady Doctor under the Municipal Council, Ganganagar.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant was appointed by the Local Self- Government Department, Government of Rajasthan by order of appointment dated 27.11.1974, and posted as Lady Doctor under the Municipal Council, Ganganagar.

facts.text: There was a stipulation in the order of appointment that she was being posted purely on temporary basis for the period of six months or till the candidate selected by the Rajasthan Public Service Commission is available, whichever is earlier.

anchor.surface_text: There was a stipulation in the order of appointment that she was being posted purely on temporary basis for the period of six months or till the candidate selected by the Rajasthan Public Service Commission  hereinafter referred to as the Service Commission  is available, whichever is earlier.

facts.text: The working period of the appellant continued to be extended.

facts.text: The appointment was made in exercise of powers conferred under Section 308 of the Rajasthan Municipalities Act, 1959 read with Rules 26 and 27 of the Rajasthan Municipal Service Rules, 1963.

facts.text: Though the appellant was selected by the Service Commission in October 1976 and August 1982 she did not join pursuant to such selection.

facts.text: On 1.10.1988 appellants services were terminated on the ground that the candidate selected by the Service Commission was available.

anchor.surface_text: On 1.10.1988 appellants services were terminated on the ground that the candidate selected by the Service Commission was available.

facts.text: Challenging such dismissal, appellant filed a writ petition bearing number 3739 of 1988 before the Rajasthan High Court.

anchor.surface_text: Challenging such dismissal, appellant filed a writ petition bearing number 3739 of 1988 before the Rajasthan High Court.

facts.text: Interim order of stay was passed on 12.10.1988 by the High Court.

anchor.surface_text: Interim order of stay was passed on 12.10.1988 by the High Court with the direction that the appellant was number to be relieved from her post if she was number already relieved.

facts.text: Subsequently the interim order was made absolute by order dated 21.3.1989.

anchor.surface_text: Subsequently the interim order was made absolute by order dated 21.3.1989.

facts.text: By judgment dated 5.3.1993, learned Single Judge held that termination of appellants services was illegal.

anchor.surface_text: By judgment dated 5.3.1993, learned Single Judge held that termination of appellants services was illegal since order was passed ignoring of the fact that she had put in 14 years of service.

facts.text: The authorities were directed to adjudge her suitability within a period of one month and regularize her services with all benefits available to a substantively appointed member of the service.

facts.text: The State of Rajasthan filed appeal before the Division Bench of the Rajasthan High Court.

holdings.text: The appellants termination from service is in order as the appointment was temporary under Rule 27 and a PSC selected candidate was available.

anchor.surface_text: The only point involved in this appeal is whether the appellants termination from service is in order. Factual scenario which is almost undisputed is as follows- The appellant was appointed by the Local Self-

holdings.reasoning_summary: Appointment explicitly temporary with condition to end when PSC candidate available; continued on extensions without PSC concurrence beyond one year violating Rule 27(2); Division Bench correctly held no right to post.

holdings.text: There is no scope for regularization unless the initial appointment was on regular basis through PSC.

anchor.surface_text: Unless the initial recruitment is regularized through a prescribed agency, there is noscope for a demand for regularization. It is true that an ad-hoc appointee cannot be replaced by another ad-hoc appointee only a legally selected candidate can replace the ad-hoc or temporary appointee.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Initial appointment under Rule 27 temporary; no PSC selection; long service does not confer right; precedents like Piara Singh not general rule for regularization.

holdings.text: No presumption of Service Commission's concurrence can be drawn from grant of extensions.

anchor.surface_text: Another plea of the appellant needs to be noted. With reference to the extension granted it was contended that a presumption of the Service Commissions concurrence can be drawn, when extensions were granted from time to time. This plea is without any substance.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rule 27(2) mandates explicit reference after one year; extensions only during initial effectiveness; no basis for presumption post-one year.

holdings.text: The principle of legitimate expectation has no application on the facts of this case.

anchor.surface_text: What remains to be considered is the plea of legitimate expectation. The principle of legitimate expectation is still at a stage of evolution as pointed out in De Smith Administrative Law  5th Edn. Para 8.038 .

holdings.reasoning_summary: No representation, promise, or past practice creating expectation; mere continuance insufficient; requires reliance and detriment; public interest in PSC recruitment overrides.

holdings.text: Learned Single Judge erred; Division Bench rightly set aside direction for regularization.

anchor.surface_text: Learned Single Judge was swayed by the fact that for a longer period the concurrence was not sought for from the Commission and held that the inaction gave an undefeatable right to the appellant. The view was rightly set at naught by the Division Bench.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Single Judge ignored clear terms of Rule 27(2); nature of temporary employment explicit; no automatic right from inaction.

holdings.text: An ad-hoc or temporary appointee can only be replaced by a regularly selected candidate; availability means selected by PSC, not necessarily joined.

anchor.surface_text: It is true that an ad-hoc appointee cannot be replaced by another ad-hoc appointee only a legally selected candidate can replace the ad-hoc or temporary appointee.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Explicit stipulation in appointment order; PSC selected candidates available in 1976 and 1982; appellant did not join despite selection.

holdings.text: Challenge to dismissal on ground of long continuance as ad-hoc employee without substance.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Precedents distinguish: no general rule relaxing recruitment for long service; Article 142 exceptional, not applicable routinely.
